Translated_Text: bundle of stalks of corn, or of wood
he broke something into two parts, cannot be used with first person plural
break something while putting it in
break something to give a part to somebody, in imperative it has an offensive meaning
a branch of that tree has broken
I did not pass by there
he built for me/ build for me!
pl. ‘he built many things’ (not the same thing many times)
I covered myself with a cloth

Primary_Text: ɓàràká-f-ɓàràkú lú tá tsá xàlá tá mndú tá mtútà yá
Translated_Text: one celebrated (through a trotting dance) the advanced age of the dead person
he courted a girl unsuccesfully (not: he tried to court a girl)
and now they are chewing it (the beans)
he disobeyed, plural through reduplication and a insertion,
he didn’t follow the prescribed order of activities in a ceremony
he burned only firewood, the other things that were nearby he left
he burned wood in order to get charcoal
he burned a part of the firewood
burning, in the process of burning
many things in the process of burning
'Mbitsa has threatened children, 'na' cannot be omitted;
he reprimanded (no specific addressee is implied)
one has made them agree; with high tone on the verb (goal marker), and low tone on nà the meaning is quite different;
one has gone to make someone them agree
'I hit him'; when the object is non-human, the source extension is not used
hit someone to chase him out

Primary_Text: tsá lá xámáyádzì káy kàgì dzà-gá-p-tá dúlá krámásá
Translated_Text: The people of Hamman Yaji immediately shot their rifles
Dukwa has immunized his house against attacks
'he made me immune to attacks' (this protection is usually made with some plant products, not through verbal means)
'he smashed small pieces of something', not 'he smashed something into small pieces'
one has ploughed the field for him
and she transformed it into beer
they should cook and bring it

Primary_Text: ngá dà-gá-ghà-tà índà grá-xà-ní tá ghzú
Translated_Text: all of his friends should cook beer and bring it there.

Primary_Text: ngá dà-ghá-tà índà grá-xà-ní tá ghzú
Translated_Text: all of his friends should cook beer and take it away
cook something and bring it here

Primary_Text: mbàɗ ká mbízà kà dà-tà mbúúlùk
Translated_Text: then the bean dish cooked very well
his father; can be used by members of the family or the outsiders
cook something and bring it down to a lower elevation
and they fell in’ (the speaker is in the place where they fell in)
and they fell in (the speaker is higher than the place where they fell in)
it is Rooster that hid him
ten, can be used with any round number, e.g. 10, 100. Can also be used alone, and the default interpretation is then ‘ten’.
the woman is of middle size
Mbitsa has found out about his hoe
I became unexpectedly aware of his arrival
he fixed many things, he fixed something
she put the beans on fire, cannot be used with sígà ‘pot’ as an object.
deprive somebody of something through asking
ask for a part of something
ask for something and obtain it
try to ask something for somebody
ask for an object which will move into higher elevation
ask for something, the person who is asking is higher than the object
ask, the subject and the object are at the same level
ask just like that, without taking into consideration the object asked
he sewed the clothing for the child
(generally things) germinated, but the corn did not germinate
he heated up something and went
he heated up water, one needs to reheat water
and he ate it up (literally: put it into himself)
it is dog that is barking
he dried the germinated guinea corn
and germinated guinea corn has dried
chase toward here (the animal moved toward here)
he laughed, he was happy, proud
laugh a bit, with 'p': out ,extension means 'laughing at'
the in-laws burst out laughing mocking him
he sent (no inanimate object can be added to this verbal form)
he sent Mbitsa to accompany Prafé (Prafé is the main person going, he knows the destination)
it is me who will send you

Primary_Text: mghám tá ghùn-áf-t-í’í ndá xwáyá ndá xwáyá
Translated_Text: it is the chief that sent me urgently
my shirt dried, not ‘the sun/my wife dried my shirt’
he surpassed him in height or age, a polite way of saying that he is old
Mbitsa measured the mouth of the door
Mbitsa realized that he had forgotten his hoe

Primary_Text: gwàɗ-gwàɗá mbitsá tá ngání mà gwàɗà

Translated_Text: speak instead of me, with the extension 'g' the addressee can be added

Primary_Text: pgháfì tà gá krì mà mákwà mí dzà dúkwá
Translated_Text: Prafé is a mediator between the fiancé of Dukwa and Dukwa
he has already been frightened, ungrammatical with the extension 'va'

Primary_Text: gúyá-f-gúyà xə̀n tá vghá ndá zwánì

Translated_Text: disappear one by one, leaving the place empty

Primary_Text: yàwú hldrá-f-tà-ká tá hlná ká í’í ɗáwà-n-tà dà mbítsá
Translated_Text: I asked Mbitsa when he started work

Primary_Text: hlə̀v-í-ɗ-í-p-hlə̀vá ndá sná-ká rí sárák, hlə̀v-í-ɗ-í-p-hlə̀vá
Translated_Text: You understand, stick, hit them for me
he planted up a large portion of a field
he poured a bit of beer upon it
I found him stealing (he was stealing)
he spread the germinated corn on a flat stone, no other forms of the verb appear to be allowed
stop a part of the moving objects (e.g. part of a herd)
he warmed up with the sun
he warmed up with the fire (one cannot say 'the sun warmed him up')
he burned himself, for transitive meaning see 'fwá': heat up something
one has to wake him up
'he left the Rooster’s’, literally: he got up from Rooster’s
he left the remnants of food (head of food)
leave, about a part of the subjects,
leave in order to arrive somewhere
'and they descended', this verbal form is used preferably with plural subject: 'hlí’í hlí’í'
he ground flour on a grinding stone
they are sated, no reduplicated form, in the third person singular only stative form is possible
'it ended on it' e.g. rain ended falling ungrammatical with 'va'
a child who finished his studies
end prematurely, e.g. when the bricks end before the construction of the house is finished

Primary_Text: kà’á ká xdə́-xà kɗiŋà-gá-p-tà tà ghùrúm
Translated_Text: when the Hdi spotted them from inside the cave

Primary_Text: klígtà tsá mndú tá klàdágháptà yá ná grághá yà
Translated_Text: the man who took you there is your friend

Primary_Text: ’tsá mndú tá klígtà yá nágráɗá yà
Translated_Text: the man who took you there is your friend
do not bring it down here
he took it out (of the pot) and ate it up
take a woman, i.e. marry; not *klá zà’ál for ‘take a husband’
he brought something on his head
And the Cat devoured the Rooster
he caught me and put me out
he caught something and brought it for me
Mbitsa will not catch me and throw me out
catch and take to a higher elevation
the market got emptied (because people were forced to escape)

Primary_Text: ìmí tá pyàf-tà kòl-tsì kà sá ghà
Translated_Text: it is water that prevented him from coming
'il l'a attendu'; pas de codage morphologique pour 'attendre un peu'
it tormented me; ungrammatical with first person object realized by 'i' only
'he loved a bit' or 'he tried to love'
expression meaning: 'here I raised myself above (the rest)'

Primary_Text: kàp-á-n-kàpá xdí tá ghǝ̀ŋ ndá hàmanyàjì
Translated_Text: Hdi tried to make uprising against Haman Yaji
'he is arrogant' or 'he got up above others'
they took the meat off the head (of a cow)
it ached him, the same meaning as preceding
and the darkness surprised him on the road
'and the darkness surprised me on the road
leave (Pl) it for us,” they said.

Primary_Text: lə́má-f-lə́mà tá zwàŋgà-nì tà dzà’á tù lúmà
Translated_Text: he forbade his son who was going to the market
he fought, he forbade, one cannot use this verb in the equivalent of 'he fought against me'
they fought against each other (not against another group)

Primary_Text: lmá-lmà lmá-f-lmá tí-’í kà zá skwì
làɓà-ná-f-làɓà zwáŋàɗà tá ɓìdá ndá vàrà
Translated_Text: my child mixed up millet with beans
millet and beans got mixed up
one should mix it with goat excrement
one has to dig for him
he can eat (literally: he can eat things for eating)
he changed, one has to change
water ran, the transitive use with God as subject with respect to water (rain), and cow as subject with respect to milk
I am already cured, ungrammatical with 'va'
I washed him, a nominal object follows cognate object and is preceded by the preposition tá
eat mush with eggs instead of meat, with no sauce
he ate mush with eggs but without sauce
it (rope) got squeezed because of the movement of wind
he wrung my hand, ungrammatical without extensions *mndà-mndà
tell somebody who is in a higher position than the speaker
tell from afar, send a message
one should turn it off for me, not allowed with '?í'
he lied to me, see also 'tsákálá': lie
he has shown something to me

Primary_Text: másə́-gl- más-ú-n-ú-s-másà tá rdí tà wùbìsím, kà másə́-gl-tá-tsí
Translated_Text: and he was again applying the ointment
he applied oil on his mouth
The only extension allowed with this verb is 'f': up

Primary_Text: ndɓá ndɓá ngárgwà tá dzvú dà mbítsá

Translated_Text: he filled a calabash for him
the person got tired from carrying wood
it flew away, he went out driving
that car drove at high speed
Rooster, after having done some work (literally: after spending some time at work)

Primary_Text: kà yàwú ndzà-kw-à-gá-p-tà xdí màndá ghàlíyá

Translated_Text: one has to make them sit down
be dressed, literally: be with cloth
he returned running!, serves as numeral formative to form numerals between 11 and 19, in the construction 'ghwán' (10) 'ndá num'
he went and returned with his thoughts
he approached the calabash, i.e. he moved the calabash towards him
she made him mount the horse
'he tried to close it' or 'he closed a part of something'
'he closed for himself' or 'he closed too much'

Primary_Text: tà ngì’í tsá mndù kùl ɗùghwánà kúyà
Translated_Text: the man makes those noises hence he is not well (literally: not healthy)
he got a glimpse of me at the market
he saw me at the market (for a longish time)
one has to get him (a menace)
that is all that concerns the school

Primary_Text: ká-’á nghà-dá-tà ná zwàn-à-ní mà sígà
Translated_Text: and he saw that his children were in the pot

Primary_Text: mándá xìyá tà n`gh-í tá kághá
Translated_Text: I see you as a guinea corn e.i. you are very beautiful
it overwhelmed him, cannot take nominal object, no reduplicated form without extensions: *nànà

Primary_Text: tá xàɗú ntfàŋ ngá núwá-f-tá mndrá-ní wà
Translated_Text: there was no glue to close his anus
he already fattened a cow for himself
he remained; if the nominal subject is added, the last tone of the verb becomes high
Mbitsa remained; with an object pronoun: leave, abandon

Primary_Text: z-ú-zà tá hlúí dímdím kùl pɗá-ná-tà
Translated_Text: he ate all the meat and did not leave anything
he poured out something for him
then, the bean dish was poured out
then, the bean dish was poured out and brought
I drank a lot of beer
and he put them in the pot
the pot broke a little bit
he paid you back (the wrong done to him)
he made a ceremony of venerating his dead parents
he made the ceremony of libation
he looked for me, but he didn’t find me
he looked for me, and found me

Primary_Text: pàxá pàxá tá kóɓù mà zlíbì
Translated_Text: look for money in the pocket
he thanked the chief; ungrammatical without 'ná'
the corn rotted; with object markers becomes transitive, and means 'kill many'
he hunted a daman (he got it)
he made his cow lose weight
she bought you something to eat
The black boss is going to sell…
they danced the dance of the bull
he obeyed me; in order to make predication object directional, the third person object 'n' must be added to the verb
he heard my speech, my words
he drank the upper part of a liquid
he drank some beer (there is beer left)
he emptied a container by drinking up the content
he came (to the place of speech)
he is nasty, lit. he is in meanness
'he undressed me' or 'he or she undressed for me'
bless, the complement of the verb can be either saliva or mouth
we (dual inclusive) were blessed, literally: he spit us the mouth; blessing involves father spitting on the child, and pronouncing some incantations

Primary_Text: tsɗá-ghw-tsɗá tá xàɗík tà ghǝ́ŋgà kfùr
Translated_Text: he gathered the soil from a metal plate
to gather in one place and put in another
he emptied the container and sent away the content
Do people gather as they used to?
one has gathered the stalks of corn

Primary_Text: kà tsà-f-tá-xə̀ŋ tá xgà tsá gúyá tá ghə́´ŋ-á-táŋ yá
Translated_Text: And they named their association AERT
cut and put on, e.g. cut the stomach of an animal and put its content on stones, for divination
he cut himself (no other object may be added)
he evened up the wall (damaged by rain)
he husked the corn i.e. to husk fresh guinea corn to eat it raw
he coughed ('másá?ì': the flu/tubercolosis), the only object allowed with this verb
he swept the entrance to the house
he sold me a lie, he lied to me

Primary_Text: txà-f-txà tá tìlì tà kwàtá ghǝ́ŋ
Translated_Text: he drew a moon on a head calabash

Primary_Text: tà t-áy-lú tá ɗàlì mà xìlbá
Translated_Text: the sauce is served in the xilba pot
he fetched the sauce and put it on something
he tried to burst the pot
I think it is exactly at the market

middle wife; i.e. wife married after another wife; see 'màrkwà sánághà': the last wife, i.e. the wife married last (used only in reference to a situation when one has several wives) These terms are used with respect to one’s own wife and other people’s wives
I am in the middle of these people
pull a lot, collapse (about river shore, house)
she learned to sew on a sewing machine
don’t learn the dance of others i.e. go your own way
It is Rooster that arrived first.
to diminish (comes from ‘take from the top’)
he tasted the sauce a little bit; the transitive predication ungrammatical without 'ná' or 'n'
I found him sitting; see 'zbà': search

Primary_Text: tsá mndú-xà yá tá tàxá-f-tá sá-ghà
Translated_Text: These people are the first to arrive

Primary_Text: vl-íxà-tà xwáyá tá vl-í-xà-tà tá bàlóŋ

Translated_Text: I will make my wife return (to us), he said
I jumped (e.g., seeing a snake, I jumped)

Primary_Text: wày, wànáftà, wá-ná-f-wá ná máhláká-ɗá ná
Translated_Text: Surround my house with a wall
they are fighting (they are fighting against us/him etc.)

Primary_Text: xdí xà tà dzrá gwàɗá mìstá tsínìk
Translated_Text: Hdi sitting under a mahogany tree settling a dispute

Primary_Text: xgà-n-tì í tá ùvá wà ká yàghí
Translated_Text: “I will not invite the cat” said the squirrel.

Primary_Text: snà-n-sn-íyù tá xn-áy-tá n tá hlà
Translated_Text: I heard that they slaughtered a cow; see 'xná': slaughter
it tired him, indirect object cannot be added

Primary_Text: tà xíɗá-y tá xíɗá-kw índà fìtík
Translated_Text: he enjoys himself all the time

Primary_Text: tsá mndú yá tà xàní dágálá
xúxúrà-f- xúxúrà tá ghrùm tá sú
Translated_Text: he made a hole in a tree

Primary_Text: xùzlà xà skálú tà dzáw lú tà lúmá

Translated_Text: she ground flour on a grinding stone
she gave birth to a daughter
this tree multiplied, this yield a lot
it fell on the ground, on its own
he ate up something (he emptied the container of the food)
he ate the upper part of the food
the termites have eaten part of the hay
the termites have eaten its bottom (the rest is there)
